Award.AwardTitle: DDRIG: Expanding Phonological Typology through Kaco' Sound Patterns

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emily Olsen, under the direction of Juliette Blevins of the City University of New York, will conduct a study of the sound system of Kaco', an undescribed minority language spoken in rural Ratanakiri Province, Cambodia. Kaco' is an Austro-Asiatic language of the Mon Khmer family and, like other languages of this family, Kaco' is phonologically complex and unusual. Olsen's study of Kaco' will therefore advance knowledge of what types of phonological systems are possible for human languages. In addition, because sounds and sound processes provide important clues to language relatedness, Olsen's description of Kaco' sound patterns will facilitate hypotheses on the features that are unique to or characteristic of the Austroasiatic language family and will help disambiguate historical relationships between languages and speaker groups of the region.

The primary research questions involve the description of the sound patterns of the Kaco' language including contrastive vowels and consonants and their phonetic variants, the structure of Kaco' syllables; laryngeal contrasts in Kaco'syllables and their phonetic properties and phonological domains. Olsen's study will focus on documenting complex syllable structure and the role between syllables within a word. She will document phonation (vocal fold vibration) and tonogenesis (e.g., the birth of tone through consonant weakening).

In order to pursue these research questions, Olsen will collect speech samples from Kaco' speakers from several villages. Her data samples will include recordings of freeform narratives, wordlists, songs, and community folklore. The resulting corpus will be the first cultural and linguistic resource of its kind for use by Kaco' people. This resource will enable development of literacy materials for the community, including a Kaco' orthography, children's books and recordings, and a dictionary.

Data from this project will be archived at the Lund University's Repository &
Workspace for Austroasiatic Intangible Heritage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the duration of the award period, the co-PI elicited and collected sound recordings in Kachut, a Kachok (Kaco') village in Ratanakiri Province, Cambodia.

This research culminated in a dissertation that describes the sound patterns of the language. This dissertation will serve as a basis for comparative analysis of Kachok and other Bahnaric and Austroasiatic languages in order to develop strong hypotheses about the relatedness of languages in the region.  The dissertation also proposes a novel analysis of the sesquisyllable, a structural feature of many Southeast Asian languages. As a result, the work resulting from this awarded project engages in scholarly discourse relevant to phonological analysis more broadly.

This research took place at an important time. Ratanakiri is an ethnically and linguistically diverse place, and the Kachok people are a small minority group living among other larger tribes in a rural, underserved area. The cultural and linguistic landscape is rich and Kachok people have largely positive attitudes about their tribe and their language. Even over the course of this award period, a newly-constructed bridge increased traffic in their small village, and this accessibility is likely to have other consequences in the near future. While many of these consequences will have positive effects (healthcare, education, infrastructure, access to resources), they will also likely threaten the stability of the Kachok language in its unique context. Kachok villagers often asked about the research goals of the awarded project, and were very responsive to the notion of endangered language documentation and preservation. They expressed interest in language maintenance and documentation.  Hopefully, this work validated and confirmed language preservation and maintenance as worthy goals for their community.

The awarded project culminated in a complete dissertation entitled "The Sound Patterns of Kachok in Bahnaric and North-Bahnaric Context."  Materials are/will be archived with the RWAAI Archive at Lund University.
